title: Alternating Bicep Curl
description:
Alternating Bicep Curls are a classic arm workout that targets the biceps brachii, helping to build size and strength.

How to Perform:
- Stand upright, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing forward.
- Curl one dumbbell up toward your shoulder, keeping your elbow close to your torso.
- Squeeze your biceps at the top, then slowly lower the dumbbell back down.
- Repeat with the other arm, alternating between left and right.

Muscles Worked:
✔ Biceps brachii (main target)
✔ Brachialis (helps add arm thickness)
✔ Forearms (secondary engagement)

This exercise helps build stronger, more defined arms while improving muscle symmetry and control. 💪

articles.title: DO's
list: ✔ Maintain Proper Posture – Stand upright with your chest up, shoulders back, and core engaged.
✔ Keep Your Elbows Stationary – Your elbows should stay close to your torso without moving forward.
✔ Use a Full Range of Motion – Curl the weight all the way up and fully extend your arm at the bottom.
✔ Lift and Lower Slowly – Control both the lifting (concentric) and lowering (eccentric) phases to maximize tension.
✔ Squeeze at the Top – Hold the contraction for a second at the peak of the movement.
✔ Use a Challenging but Manageable Weight – Choose a weight that allows controlled movement without cheating.
✔ Breathe Correctly – Exhale as you lift the dumbbell and inhale as you lower it.

articles.title: DONT's
list: ❌ Don’t Swing or Use Momentum – Avoid rocking your body or using your back to lift the weight.
❌ Don’t Shrug Your Shoulders – Keep your shoulders relaxed to prevent unnecessary strain.
❌ Don’t Lock Out Your Elbows – Keep a slight bend at the bottom to reduce joint stress.
❌ Don’t Rush the Movement – Performing slow, controlled reps is more effective than fast, sloppy ones.
❌ Don’t Lean Back – If you’re arching your back, the weight is too heavy.
❌ Don’t Drop the Dumbbell Quickly – Lower it slowly to maintain tension and build strength.
❌ Don’t Let Your Wrists Bend Too Much – Keep them straight to avoid unnecessary strain.
